data.text: Can't Decide: Wood Stove or JetBoil?

Stove choice. No experience and hoping for feedback. I am drawn to a Solo stove - wood fuel - but also considering a Jetboil. A little worried that the Solo will be dirty so will require some thought for how to pack and obviously there are potential issues of being able to find appropriate wood but I figure a sandwich bag of wood pellets as a backup would solve those problems. The Solo is less expensive but after getting a pot probably it comes out close enough. Thoughts/recommendations please

Look on Amazon for Ohuhu stove works on same physics as Solo stove. Mine burns clean and come with a carry bag. Quick to boil water. I also like the Trangia small alcohol stoves. Also sold on Amazon. I use a section of the Ohuhu stove as a wind cover for the alcohol stove. I use HEET that comes in the yellow container.
data.author: D Gerit Slikkers

data.text: This alcohol burner works well with the solo stove.
data.author: Tom Sawyer

data.text: We did a 3 way contest as to which stove heated a quart of water to boiling fastest. Gas alcohol, wood. The wood stove won, so we took the wood stove. It rained every day so we never had dry fuel, the cooking times were horrid.
data.author: Thomas Wilson

data.text: Being from the Great Pacific Northwet, I had already decided that wood, although tempting, wouldn't be a good choice. You've just confirmed it. Thanks.
data.author: Jim McCorison

data.text: Coleman and Ozark Trail ( Walmart) have really cheap propane one burner stoves. Coleman also has a single burner duel fuel stove. These are the cheap options not solo which requires skill and dry available wood.
data.author: Gordo S. Groundchuck

data.text: Carry the wood stove in a freezer Ziploc baggie. I use a MSR Pocket Rocket 2 stove. But fuel on the AZT is hard to come by with all the hikers using the same stove canisters.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: Super small and cheap.. never let me down. For alternative..
data.author: Shawn Bowman

data.text: Jetboil is the way forward. Expensive but worth every penny.
data.author: Gary Joyce

data.text: Get the firemaple x2 or x3 1 on 1 ali express clone for about 50 euros so 1/3 the price of a jetboil ;) mine has been going strong for over 2 years still in use only the piezo igniter gave out but can be replaced
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: Do not buy before considering other options too. My recommendation is to always use a petrol (gasoline) stove on tours longer than a couple of days, because the fuel is so universally available and cheap. And when I say petrol (gasoline) I mean the stuff you buy from a petrol station (gas station) to put in a car. The stove should run on that, not only naptha or "white gas". Note: when carrying liquid fuels on a tour, especially petrol (gasoline), carry it outside your panniers. I use a standard fuel bottle in a standard bicycle bottle cage (my touring bike handily has fittings to carry a "third" bottle cage, under the down tube.
data.author: Mark Severs

data.text: Im going with the "use what i have" method on my first tour which will be a dual burner propane camp stove. It can also double as a heater...
data.author: Justin Morrison

data.text: For me ( and such a personal matter!) MSR dragonfly (or similar) all the way! Multi fuel so wherever you are you can get what you need. Wood is too filthy and weather/environment dependant. Have run my msr on diesel/unleaded/meths/paraffin…. And never had a problem that a good clean wouldn’t fix. Also, super light, fits in a pan and virtually indestructible. Noisy but can boil 2 litres of water as fast as my kettle at home. Love it.
data.author: Em Fedz

data.text: Wood burning seems completely impractical. Gasoline powered ones are great from a fuel availability point of view. The MSR ones are the best I think from weight/reliability point of view but you may struggle to find fuel some places.
data.author: Rich Langston

data.text: Both great choices if you only want to boil water, rather than actually 'cook'. Both are exceedingly poor choices to try to 'cook' with, the Solo since maintaining a wood fire for even heating is a nightmare, & the Jetboil quickly goes so hot you scorch everything. If you intend to actually 'cook', then you need something that can get very hot for a few minutes to get started quickly, then adjust way down low into a simmer to tenderize things for more than 20 minutes. Rice is a good example.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: do you have a suggestion? I like to cook and as you said, jet boil can’t simmer.
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: SOTO Windmaster. My extravagant purchase at $65USD on Amazon. Recommended by Dan Becker (youtube backpacker). Always works in windy conditions. I tried a jetboil. Do I really need my water boiling in a minute versus 3 minutes? (Hint: no). A 200 ml (about 8 ounces) fuel canister will easily last a week on tour cooking twice a day (oatmeal for breakfast, pasta with meat for dinner). I don't really "cook" with the stove, just heat water or heat a canned dinner. Keep it as simple as possible.
data.author: Andrew Hill

data.text: You may not need water boiling that fast but a small JetBoil canister will last a month using it twice a day. Sure beats having to replace it every week IMO.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: i stand corrected. I was using 100 ml cans of fuel on my last trip. Lasted 10 days.
data.author: Andrew Hill

data.text: Same size I use as well. They nest into the pot. Will use the larger ones for car camping.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Trangia
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: Had my Trangia for 25+ years. Never let me down. Recently bought a jet boil which is amazing except for one major downside is that the jet boil branded gas cartridges aren’t self sealing so once it’s screwed onto the burner then it has to stay on until it’s spent
data.author: Alan Prior

data.text:
I have a jet boil for touring for boiling water and cooking food, easy to use. https://velotouring.fun/review-jetboil-zip
Review JetBoil Zip
velotouring.fun
data.author: Martin Clarke

data.text:
https://youtu.be/th0I6febJAU
Multifuel Emergency Stove
youtube.com
data.author: Mak McCjmak

data.text: Depends on where you travel as to what fuel is available. I have use gasoline in Mongolia but I prefer butane when available.
data.author: Barry Andrews

data.text: It also depends on where you're going - there's an international standard for camping gas bottle fittings, except in France where the chances of getting one are nil. I have a small spirit stove I've had for 30 years. Never struggled to find something it'll burn.
data.author: Simon Thompson

data.text: I prefer my JetBoil. My Stash weighs 7.1 ounces and boils water in a few minutes. Wood stoves can be tricky cause they’re banned during most burn bans.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: It depends on what you want to do. Some places only allow pressurized fuel stoves. I like to cook so I prefer alcohol stoves. I admit that they are slower and subject to the wind. Wood stoves are nice but more for companionship for me. Can't always find fuel, and if I bring it anyway....... Try several things you eat on each.
data.author: Robert Crow
